 4.1.5  Mechanical Integrity
The Heat Treat system and equipment is maintained to help prevent equipment failures that
could endanger employees and contractors, the public, or the environment. The mechanical integrity
(preventive maintenance) program includes an inspection and testing program to help identify
equipment deterioration and damage well before the equipment can fail.

 4.1.6  Management of Change
The Management of Change procedure is a written procedure that requires the review and approval
of all proposed changes to the Heat Treat system.  This includes chemicals, equipment, technology, and 
procedures to help ensure that the change does not negatively affect safe operations.  All changes other
 than replacement-in-kind (e.g., replacing a valve with an identical valve) must be approved through the
 Management of Change procedure.  This helps to ensure that inadvertent consequences of changes are 
prevented, safety consequences of changes are addressed, affected process safety information and 
procedures are updated, and affected employees are notified of the changes.

4.1.7  Pre-startup Safety Review
Safety reviews of new or modified processes are performed before placing them into service to help
ensure their safe operation.  This review confirms that:
  ¿  construction activities and equipment are in accordance with design specifications;
  ¿  adequate safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place;
  ¿  employee training has been completed; and
  ¿  for a covered process (regulated process), a Process Hazard Analysis has been performed if
  the process is new, or management of change requirements have been completed if an existing
  process has been modified.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
FAG BEARINGS CORPORATION
Joplin, Missouri
Newton County

OVERVIEW
FAG Bearings Corporation is committed to operating in a manner that is safe for our employees,
contractors, the surrounding community, and the environment.  To meet this commitment, we have
established systems to ensure safe operation of plant processes, which includes the safe and proper
handling of hazardous substances at the plant.  One component of these systems is a Risk
Management Program (RMP), which manages the risks involved with using hazardous substances. 
FAG's RMP complies with the requirements of the Environmental Protection Agency's
(EPA's) regulation 40 CFR  68, Accidental Release Prevention Requirements:  Risk Management
Programs.  This regulation is also referred to as the RMP rule.  One of the requirements of the
RMP rule is to submit an executive summary in the Risk Management Plan  describing
the RMP at our facility.  This document is intended to satisfy the executive summary
requirement of the RMP rule and to provide a description of the RMP.  

FAG Bearings Corporation in Joplin, Mo. has a heat treat operation which utilizes propane that will be above the threshold quantity limit of 10,000 pounds.  This RMP along with the PSM plan presents a comprehensive program designed to reduce the potential for unwanted releases, fires, or catastrophic explosions of highly flammable chemicals.  The Propane is used as a fuel and atmospheric control for the Heat Treat system.  Design engineering led to the facility having four individual 1,000 gallon tanks connected and stored together to provide the Propane into Heat Treat.
FAG Bearings / Joplin, Mo.  Risk Management Program consists of three elements:

  1. A hazard assessment to identify (a) the potential offsite consequences of hypothetical accidental
  releases and (b) accidents that have occurred during the last 5 years associated with the
  substances regulated by the RMP rule (see Sections 3 and 5 of this executive

summary);
  2. A prevention program to help maintain and safely operate processes containing significant
  quantities of substances regulated by the RMP rule (see Section 4 of this executive summary);
  and
  3. An emergency response program to provide guidance to the plant for responding to accidental
  releases of regulated substances from processes covered by the RMP rule (see Section 6 of this
  executive summary).

Although the RMP helps ensure that FAG¿s RMP covered system is maintained and operated in a safe 
manner,  it is only one component of the plant's overall safety program.  In fact, a comprehensive safety 
program exists that establishes many levels of safeguards against accidents.

CONSIDERATIONS
Preventing releases of the regulated substances used.
When a regulated substance is used, the equipment that contains it is carefully designed, built, and
operated to reduce the likelihood of an accidental release.  All applicable federal, state, corporate,
and industry standards are strictly adhered to in the design, construction, and operation of the
equipment.

Limiting damage from a release or fire.
FAG's main objective is to prevent the accidental release or fire / explosion involving Propane from 
occurring.  In the unlikely event of a release, employees are trained to recognize incidents, quickly 
assess the severity of an incident, and respond to mitigate the incident.  Coordination with the county's 
Local Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC) is crucial to protect the health and safety of the 
surrounding community.  Emergency planning efforts have been performed and will continue with the 
local officials with Newton  County Emergency Services.  In short, actions have been taken to ensure 
appropriate plans are in place to minimize the impact of an incident on our employees and the 
community.
FAG Bearings safety program consists of a number of elements, many of which are beyond what is
required by the RMP rule.  This RMP executive summary is writ

ten to describe only those parts
of the safety program required by the RMP rule for FAG Bearings.

ELEMENTS
 1. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
FAG is committed to the safety of its employees and contractors, the public, and to the protection
of the environment.  All appropriate steps have been taken to prevent an incident involving Propane.  
These steps include (a) training programs for personnel, (b) programs to help ensure safety in the 
design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our process, and (c) programs to evaluate the 
hazards of our processes.

In the event of an accidental release, FAG will be prepared to respond in a manner that will be
safe for our employees and will minimize any injury to the public and the environment.  The plant
has a trained employees how to properly respond in the event of an incident. 

2.   REGULATED SUBSTANCE USED AT FAG Bearings / Joplin, MO.
FAG Bearings has one substance (Propane) in sufficient quantity to be regulated by the RMP rule.  The 
Propane used at this facility is covered by the RMP rule.  As stated  previously, Propane will be used as a 
 fuel and for atmospheric control for the heat treat process.

4.  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC
   PREVENTION STEPS
FAG Bearings / Joplin, MO.  has developed a comprehensive prevention program that complies with the
 Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA's) Process Safety Management (PSM) 
Regulation found in 29 CFR 1910.119.  For FAG Bearings, the prevention program requirements of EPA's 
RMP rule are also satisfied by this PSM program.  The following sections briefly describe the elements of 
the prevention program that address the RMP rule requirements.

 4.1  Prevention Program
The accident prevention program for Propane consists of the following 12 elements:

 4.1.1  Process Safety Information
A number of t

echnical documents are maintained and are readily available at the plant, including an
emergency preparedness plan (called the Integrated Contingency Plan, or ICP), to help ensure that
facility and local emergency responders are aware of the hazards.  The PSI include the MSDS for Propane 
that gives chemical, physical, and other hazards.  This process safety information is available to our 
employees and contractors, as well.

 4.1.2  Process Hazard Analysis
Process Hazard Analysis of the Heat Treat process involving Propane was performed and will be
 periodically updated to identify process hazards, as well as to establish recommendations that will
 improve the safe operation of the RMP covered process.  FAG established a group that  systematically 
addressed the hazards associated with operation of Heat Treat associated with Propane.  The team then 
prepared a written report describing the results of the analysis, including a list of recommendations.  
Responsibility for resolving the recommendations was assigned to plant personnel, and, when 
appropriate, changes to enhance the safety of the system were implemented.  This analysis is revised at 
least every 5 years to ensure it is current.

 4.1.3  Operating Procedures 
FAG Bearings engineers, EHS, maintenance, operators, and management worked together to develop
 and maintain operating procedures to define how tasks related to the Heat Treat involving Propane 
should be safely performed.  The operating procedures are used to train employees and serve as 
reference guides for appropriate actions to take during both normal operations and process upsets.

 4.1.4    Training
Employees are trained to safely and effectively perform their assigned tasks.  The training program
includes both initial and refresher training that covers (a) a general overview of the system, (b) the
properties and hazards of Propane, and (c) a detailed review of the operating procedures
and safe work practices.  Classroom training and demo

he cornerstones of an effective prevention program is a regular, thorough assessment.  A
program is in place to perform compliance audits of our RMP-covered processes every 3 years to
be certain the prevention program is effectively addressing the safety issues of the process.  These
audits are performed by a team that includes personnel knowledgeable in the Heat Treat system, the
RMP and PSM requirements, and safety involved with Propane.  This will help ensure safe operation of 
the Heat Treat system.  The results of the audit are documented, recommendations are resolved, and 
appropriate enhancements to the prevention program are implemented.

 4.1.9  Incident Investigation
A program is in place to investigate any incidents or near misses that could reasonably result in
serious injury to personnel, the public, or the environment so that similar accidents can be prevented
in the future.  The requirements to identify and report any incident requiring investigation are
communicated to employees.  In the event of an incident, an investigation team would be assembled,
and the investigation would be initiated as soon as possible, but always within 48 hours of the
incident.  The results of the investigation are documented, recommendations are resolved, and
appropriate process improvements are implemented.

 4.1.10 Employee Participation
A written employee participation program exists for our RMP covered process to help ensure that
the safety concerns of our employees are addressed.  This is completed within our PSM Program.  We 
encourage active participation of personnel in the prevention program activities of all processes at the
 plant.  

4.1.11 Hot Work Permits
A Hot Work Permit Program exists, which is intended to control spark or flame-producing activities
that could result in fires or explosions at Wateree Station.  This program conforms to OSHA
requirements.  Training on hot work activities and on the requirements of the hot work permit
program is included in o

ur new employee orientation.

4.1.12   Contractors
A program is in place to help ensure that contractor activities related to the RMP covered Heat Treat 
system involving Propane are performed in a safe manner.  Contractor supervisors are informed of the 
hazards of the processes on which they and their employees will work, our safe work practices, and our 
emergency response procedures.  Contractors are required to ensure that training has been performed 
for each of their employees before he/she performs work at the plant.  Routine verification that this 
training has been provided is performed.

4.2   Chemical-specific Prevention Steps
In addition to the required prevention program elements, safety features specific to the Heat Treat 
System involving Propane have been implemented.  Manual shutoff valves, alarms on the equipment,
 and other systems have been provided.

5.   FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
There have been no recordable releases or incidents involving Propane within the last five years.  




6.   EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAMS
FAG's Emergency Response Team personnel will respond to an incident within the Heat Treat system 
involving Propane.  The Integrated Contingency Plan (ICP) has been developed to help facilitate the 
evacuation of employees and to ensure the safety of FAG Bearings and local emergency responders who 
could be called on to respond to an incident.  
The ICP addresses:
  ¿  informing local emergency responders about incidents that could reasonably result in
  offsite consequences;
  ¿  providing emergency medical assistance;
  ¿  obtaining outside assistance to control and contain incidents;
  and
  ¿  plan review and upkeep.

Employees are trained to recognize and report known, or even perceived, emergency situations. 
Employees and contractors are trained in evacuation procedures.  The ICP complies with other federal 
contingency plan regulations [i.e., OSHA regulation 29 CFR 1910.38(a) and 1910.120(q)]. Hazardous 
material inventory h

as been provided to the LEPC and local fire department, as required by the 
Emergency Planning and Community Right-To-Know Act.  

7.   PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
FAG Bearings is committed to continuous improvement of the safety process using recommendations
developed through the prevention program and a program soliciting safety suggestions from our
employees.  Standard operating and safety procedures for the RMP covered process are reviewed
periodically to ensure that they are correct, and training is provided to employees on a wide variety
of safety and operating topics.
